captions.text:
DANIEL CORMIER: Man,
the stories I hear
from my mom and them.

Man I was just, I
was a rough kid.

I had knots all the time in my
head and my face from falling.
I've missed school pictures.

Almost every class picture I'm
gone because my mom wouldn't

let me go because I had some
sort of knot, or I had

something from playing in the
yard or just getting hit.

-Cormier's laughing like wow,
I can't believe I got out of
the way of those.

-A minute 11 left
in the first.
A jab from Cormier.
-Uppercut.
-Uppercut.
Down goes Silva.
Hammer fest.
Cormier has done it.
-Wow.

-Daniel Cormier has just
defeated Bigfoot.
Mama mia.
-This kid is dangerous.

DANIEL CORMIER: The money, the
bright lights, all that, the
interviews, the TV.

Above everything I love
the competition.

That's why I wrestled
as long as I did.

You know, I wrestled
in the last two
Olympics, in '04 and '08.

I walked in here as a two time
Olympian, six time US national

champion, NCAA All-American at
Oklahoma State University.

My manager, DeWayne Zinkin, he
actually started talking to me
right out of college in 2001.

And he said listen, this
is a sport for you.

He said, have you ever
been in a fight?
And I was like, yeah.
I grew up in Louisiana.

If I didn't learn to fight I was
just going to get beat up
all the time.

And even though I thought I knew
how to fight, I still got
beat up all the time.

So he kind of just kept up with
me throughout my whole
wrestling career.

And when I was ready to
fight I said, hey, I'm
ready to try it.

Is there anything
I need to do?

He said, well what I'm going to
do is fly you out to AKA.
It was a secret tryout.

I didn't know that, but I came
for about a week and I fell in

love with the place because they
had Cain and Kos and all
those guys at the time.

And about a month later I was
fighting in my first fight.

I told my cousin, the day of
my first fight, I said I'm

going to have to become a
totally different person.

Because I'm going into a cage
and I'm going to fight.

It wasn't very pretty,
but I won.

But then after the fight I
realized I'm the same person
that I've always been.

I just understand the sport
that I'm in now.
Hey, turn this off.
Come here.
You gotta do this.
BOB COOK: I'm mic'd, so.

DANIEL CORMIER: Yeah, well
you just cover it.
We know your old tricks.
Come here.

BOB COOK: Can't you wait,
like two minutes?
DANIEL CORMIER: No, no, no.
It's fucking awesome.
You're going to love it.

Come here, you're going
to love it.
It's money in your pocket.

You know I-- it's money
in your pocket.
BOB COOK: Seriously?
DANIEL CORMIER: Seriously.
BOB COOK: Go shower.
I'll meet you in a minute.

DANIEL CORMIER: How long
are you going to be?

BOB COOK: I'm going to
be like five minutes.

DANIEL CORMIER: You guys
have three minutes.
I need my Bob.

JAVIER MENDEZ: Daniel Cormier
is the biggest
jokester in our gym.
Nobody's safe from Daniel.
I'm not safe from Daniel.
He picks on me, too.

There was a point when he first
came here where he was a
little too far.

He carried to the point
where he almost
got these guys fighting.
It was all hell to stop it.

And then I just finally
told Daniel.
I go hey Daniel, it's cool.
I get what you're doing.
But you've got to stop, OK?

He's incredible at
pushing buttons.

SHAWN BUNCH: I got
away from him.
DANIEL CORMIER: Are you dizzy?

JAVIER MENDEZ: He is all
about the team, though.

He's all about companionship
and helping a teammate out.

DANIEL CORMIER: You know if
Cain's holding the belt at

heavyweight then I obviously
want to fight the guy at the

lower division more
than anyone else.
Because I want to get a belt.
I coach Cain and Russell.

We don't want to fight
each other.
Coach athletes way different.

You don't want to
hurt that guy.

And also I appreciate what Cain
did for me when I stepped
into this gym.

He immediately walked over to
me, gave me a hug, what's up

DC, and started working towards
me getting better.

Never viewed me as anything
more than a guy to train

together and get better
together.

And because of that, I don't
want to raise my hand to hurt

Cain Velasquez in any
way, shape, or form.
No.

JAVIER MENDEZ: For Daniel
Cormier, the world is
basically all his.

He can decide whatever
he wants to do.
Daniel's so gifted.
Light heavyweight,
heavyweight, it doesn't matter.

I mean the man can be
competitive and be a champ in

wherever division
he wants to go.
It's up to Daniel.

DANIEL CORMIER: Well, I think
John Jones is the best.
I really do.

And I would love to test
my skills against him.
He's an unbelievable athlete.

But I just think that we get
in that cage and it can be
fireworks, man.
My mom worked hard.
She did house cleaning.
My dad died when I was seven.

But my mom had already started
to date my step dad who raised

me from when I was
three years old.
So he's my father.

And he worked for the
City of Lafayette.

So I had two very hard
working parents.

I was one of the luckier
kids to have two
parents in the house.

When I was younger we were
on government assistance.

And then when I turned about six
my mom, she didn't want to
do that anymore.

She wanted to try and
make a way herself.
Her and my dad.
And they did.
So they worked hard.
Ready?

When I say go, all Moses is
going to go is sprawl.

And Angel's going
to crack him.
Watch, watch.
Ready, sprawl.
Good, set him to his hip.
Drop that hip, perfect.
Chris, get ready to sprawl.
Go, Chris.
It's too slow, Chris.
That's way too slow.
That's way too slow.
Diego, do it.
That's how it goes, fast.
You've got to be fast.

Chris, it can't be slow,
can't be slow.

You don't want to let down
the people that help you.

I carry the AKA flag on me
when I go in that cage.
Nice, crack down.
Step over.
Let him up.
Stay in his face.
Pull his head.
Get on his head.
Mark Anthony, get going.
You're slowing everybody down.
That's what it's all for.

Going out there and representing
yourself, your

family, your team, your gym,
your coaches, and everybody

else around you in
a positive light.
There's nothing like it.

You've got to know at some point
you're going to have to

just bite down on your
mouthpiece and fight.

That's probably the truest thing
that nobody ever tells
you

I never had to do that until I
fought Josh Barnett, where I

just had to go, OK
this is a fight.
This guy's not going anywhere.

I'd better pack my lunch
pail and get
ready to go five rounds.

And at some point everybody
has to do it.
I came out somebody different.

I came out a completely
different man.

I'm confident I can go
through anything now.

Before there's still some
concern, like man, what
happens when I get hurt?

What happens when I'm stuck
in a bad position?

You don't know how you're
going to react
until you do it.
Like it's something in me now.
I had to go--

25 minutes is tough when your
eye's bleeding and you're
stuck in a leg lock.

And the guy that you're in
front of you've punched
multiple times.

You've taken him down, you've
elbowed him, you've kicked him
in the head.

And that warrior keeps
coming forward.

Then you have to turn something
different on.

Like man, he's not
going anywhere.

I've got to start thinking
a different way.

Like how far am I willing
to go to win this fight?

And that's where I had
to go to beat Josh.

Before, I told Bob Cook, I
said I'm not going to do
armbars and Kimura locks.
Why?

Because I don't think I
can break anybody's
arm to finish a fight.

I train armbars and
Kimura locks now.

And I learned that
in that fight.

Because now I know if I
had to, I would do it.

Now I know that I'm willing
to go far to win.
-How far is far?
DANIEL CORMIER: Far.

That I'm uncomfortable
telling you.
-I'm not sure what that means.

DANIEL CORMIER: I
know you're not.

I'm just saying I'm willing
to do anything.
I want to win that fight.

I'm willing to go places
that most men aren't.
OK, break my arm.

That doesn't mean we're
done fighting.
That's what I mean.

JAVIER MENDEZ: Daniel dictates
what he wants to do.

I believe in him and in what
he can accomplish.

But his goal right now is just
take care of Frank Mir.
That's his only focus.

DANIEL CORMIER: I have so much
respect for Frank Mir.

I have so much respect
for Josh Barnett.

But when we get in the cage, we
have business to deal with.

We're going to give the
fans a good show.

We're going to give people
what they paid for.

You guys came to watch a fight,
we'll give you a fight.
I respect Frank so much.

But that doesn't mean when we
get in that cage I'm not going

to try to take his head off,
as he's going to do to me.
It's part of what it is.

You train, you fight, you show
respect at the end of it.

We're educated men and
we're family men.
We're not crazy people.

comments.text:
Cormier won that fight in my eyes.  Jones got raped by him.  Cormier got 
him in the air A La Barnett and slammed him on his head in the ground 
followed by a flurry of punches.  That's worth the 3 Jones takedowns.  The 
other rounds Cormier outboxed him except one that Cormier clearly lost it. 

Don't argue with me Jon's nuthuggers.  Next time he'll make it clear to the 
judges that Cormier is here! And don't worry.  I know when I lose my bets.  
I'll change my name to Mary this time, as agreed.

Bob﻿

comments.author: João Filipe da Costa

comments.text:
Well that would be a good fight, although I don't think Rumble would keep 
up such a pace against DC considering his hands, and the incredible 
presence he has with his grappling. Rumble does have the one punch knockout 
power than a lot of dc's former competitors didn't have. But idk DC's 
wrestling is just too ridiculous, it's so much easier for dc to flop rumble 
around like a rag doll than for Rumble to keep a consistent one-sided 
aggression or one-punch ko.

comments.author: YoureAlwaysRight

comments.text:
+Nhoj Ogn Doesn't seem like he's going to HW for now.  Probably after a few 
more fights at LHW.  He'll probably fight Cormier, Gustafsson and Anthony 
Johnson, in that order, and then maybe go to the heavyweight division.  In 
the heavyweights I think he'll blow past Alistair Overeem with an easy 
win, if Overeem is still in ufc at that time.  A difficult fight for him 
will be against JDS and he'll have to fight JDS before he fights Cain.   
That would make sense anyway.   But, UFC will do what makes money, so if 
they want him to go straight to Cain and by-pass JDS then that's the way 
it'll go.  I think he'll have to face JDS first though if Junior is still

comments.text:
The bottom line. Cormier should destroy Jones just based on skill. Why? 
Jones is a wrestler and so is Cormier. But, did Jones compete for the 
Olympic team? NO HE DIDN'T. Daniel Cormier was on the Olympic wrestling 
team. That is an incredible accomplishment. Thus, his wrestling is simply 
on another level compared to Jones. It just is.. And, yes Jones has those 
elbows. But, all cormier has to do is WRESTLEFUCK Jones for 5 rounds. 
Meaning, take down Jones. And just lay on him for 5 rounds. VICTROY!
